body.p: Cincinnati October 20th 1861.
Reverend Sir,

As I see by the last number of the Occident you received
the copy of the Israelite, sent to you by me and contain-
ing my refutation of Mr de Solla's pamphlet For you
devoted the full space of 9 words or the most of a Line
and a half to the critick of my article.

If I apply the rule of our Sages: מכלל הן אתה שומע לאו to your article
headed „Incestuous Marriages”, and I cannot see any reason
why I should not apply it, my refutation has not found
grace before your editorial eyes.

You say: „But this far the more complete and therefore
the more desirable response has appeared in the pub
lication” I have not seen Mr Nathan's or any one's else
reply beside mine and am therefore of course not able to
judge, how complete Mr N's reply is. Your critic on Mr
N's pamphlet, although covering full 2 pages of your
journal can guide me by no means, since your critic can
not claim any higher merit but to be a friend's eulogy on
the work of his friend and it is only fit to show that
you are on very good terms with and an admirer or intimate
friend of Mr N. Anything like an evidence of an impar
tial, objective critick by quotations from the criticized
work the reader seeks in vain in your article.

I have therefore to wait till I shall receive Mr N's pam
phlet, in order to find out myself, if your opinion on the completeness
if the said pamphlet is correct or not.

But I think myself justified in not only inviting you very
politely, but in requesting you most urgently and positively,
to point out to me the incompleteness of my refutation, viz
to show that I have either not refuted all arguments of
Mr de Solla or that I have done so in an unsatisfactory way.

If you are not abe to do so, you must acknowledge
the error or wrong of your indirect assertion.

I hardly think it necessary to remind you that if all
pretended proofs of de Solla are satisfactorily refuted by
my article, this my article has the same claim on complete
ness as a refutation filing a whole volume.

If it were not for so many people who have no
judgement of their own, who always inquire in a refutation,
if every passage of the refuted work is mentioned and opposed
to and with whom no article filling only one column has
any weight at all, since they measure the weight of an
article by the inch of the foot,—I say, if it were not for
those, a single column of the Israelite, containing only
the 2 proofs of פצוע דכא and ישב ממזר באשדוד would have been
fully sufficient to cause the 2 pillars of de Sollas struc
ture to fall to the ground. Every competent judge would
still have declared my refutation satisfactory and complete.

Yea, I dare say, truly qualified judges would prefer
such a refutation, since it would be more in correspon
dence with the words of our Sages בלשון קצרה
כל היכא דנפילין מילי משתערי

As you assuredly acknowledge the validity of this rule, you
must have found other defects in my article, than its brevity and
I therefore repeat my urgent request, to name those defects to me.

I have not the pleasure of knowing Mr Nathan nor have
I ever seen his newly published work or any other work of his.
I can therefore not judge yet able to judge how „fully” he is „armed for the
contest in behalf of Jewish purity.”

But if you have an infavorable opinion of my armature, as
this can be easily inferred from you article, this your opinion can
only have been produced by weak points, found out in my recently
published article. For you never had any other chance to judge
of my knowledge of our theology. We met each other only twice in our life once in Boston and the second time here. But
But neither time we discussed one topic or even one Iota of any הלכה
or שמעתא

I therefore feel myself induced to ask you again, to point me
out the errors of my refutation.

The great merit of Mr N's pamphlet in coming out in the
country; where his antagonist resides I fully acknowledge.
But I could not help well my refutation lacking this ex
cellent quality, since, of course, I cannot be expected to
go especially from here to Jamaica in order to publish my
refutation there.

And, after all, allow me, Rev. Sir, to remark you in all sub
missive reverence that you are here again in contradiction with
the words of our Sages, a fact which is, of course, most surprising
in the champion and defender of our Orthodox cause.

In corroboration of this my remark I refer you to the Mishna גרדים בשער הפשכה ישגו ולוג וכו
והעידו שני' and the annotation of the Gemara to this Mishna:
אין לך אומנות פחותה וכו'.

As I have now mentioned often enough, I cannot judge of the val
idity of your indirect reproofs of my refutation, until you please to
enumerate me all its faults in plain language.

But I come lastly to another indirect reproof which I am fully justi
fied to contradict flatly and emphatically already now.

You are pleased to say: In doing this, moreover, we discover nothing
like personality and bitterness against the aggressor, as the whole
„force of proofs is directed against the matter not the man.”
Now, do tell me, Mr Editor, where have you found one word of per
sonalities or bitterness in my article? Have I not treated the author
in the most polite manner and have only cared for the subject
not for the man who brought it forward? Have I not also pointed
this out in my refutation itself?

Perhaps you feel inclined to deny all intentional slight treatment
of my refutation, by referring me to the final passage of your ar
ticle from: „Our limited space” to the end. But I hardly think it
possible that you believe me green enough, as not to know that
the whole alluded conclusion of your article consists in mere words with
out having any serious meaning at all. Or should you, after having
waited on your readers with such a critic and such arguments as yours
are, still have such a favorable opinion of your readers, as to think them
capable to judge of the various publications for themselves? They would
then make a splendid exception of the majority of American and Eu
ropean Jews. While in our days יודעי התורה are very scarce every where, the
majority of your readers, if not all, would be חכמים ויודעי התורה.
You say, your limited space compelled you to treat the subject
briefly, and every one who casts only a glance at the last number
of the Occident must acknowledge the correctness of your statement,

For, had you not to benefit the Jewish community of America
and abroad by devoting almost 5 pages to a minute description of the
„Presentation of a Sepher in San Francisco” and by devoting another
page and 1/3 to a report on the extremly scarce rare and therefore highly
surprising occurrence of a בר מצוה in Norfolk Str. Synagogue

just think what our Orthodox cause would have lost, if those 2
matters had not become known! Of course have they the preference
to a full treatment of the Mamzer? question and a proper critic on the
different articles, speaking on this subject!!!

In order to show you that in writing all, I have written in this letter
I am not guided by partiality for my own slight work, I shall ex
tract some passages of a letter, I have received from a truly Orthodox
scholar.

I am not at liberty to mention you the name of the writer, since
perhaps he does not want me to do so. Suffice it, to say, that the alluded
Gentleman ranks high in our Orthodox camp and I doubt not that you
and I wish many others consider him an authority.
He wrote to me:

The papers you have sent me have come to hand, I congratulate
you on the tone of your article. The Rev. Mr Nathan's preface—his
work itself I have not seen—is too personal, whereas you are free
of sarcasm and bitterness.”
At the end of the letter he wrote to me:

I again repeat, of the replies I have hitherto seen yours is by
far the best so that Mr de Solla will have to acknowledge, that of
his opponents you are the most gentlemanly.”
In fine I ask you politely, to send me a copy of Mr Nathan's

pamphlet and to let me know the price thereof and in what
way I can remit the money to you. If you have an agent
here, please mention me his name and I shall pay him the
amount or send me the pamphlet through his agency.

Asking you again to point me out the defects of my re
futation either in a private letter or publicly in your
Journal.
I am, Rev. Sir, your obedient
